Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Distension Pressure on Long Saphenous Vein Grafts in CABG

Background: Long saphenous vein grafts (LSVGs) are essential in coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), but endothelial damage during preparation can lead to graft failure. This study investigates the effect of unregulated distension pressure on LSVG endothelium.

Methods: In this prospective, single-center randomised controlled trial, 21 paired vein samples from CABG patients were randomised into non-distended (group A) and distended (group B) groups. Histological and CD31 immunohistochemical analyses assessed endothelial cell loss. Pressure was recorded using different syringe sizes. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Outcome assessors were blinded.

Results: Distended veins showed significantly higher endothelial cell loss (31.95% ± 31.31) compared to non-distended veins (11.67% ± 28.65) (p = 0.034). CD31 immunohistochemistry confirmed greater loss in distended veins (p = 0.001). Pressure with a 20-cc syringe was lower (44.5 mmHg) than with a 10-cc syringe (92.75 mmHg). Pre-existing endothelial injury was noted in 36% of diabetic patients. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: Unregulated distension pressure during LSVG preparation is linked to increased endothelial damage. Controlled distension is crucial for preserving graft integrity. Trial registration: [Number]. Funding: [Source].
